thread.section_title: Travel News, Tips, and Guides - USATODAY.com
thread.title: Photo tour: Celebrate Hawaii statehood day
thread.title_full: Photo tour: Celebrate Hawaii statehood day

author: USA TODAY
title: Photo tour: Celebrate Hawaii statehood day
text:
Stand-up paddleboarding is a popular activity in the Hawaiian islands. Candyce Stapen Fullscreen The first thing that comes to mind when you think Hawaii -- the 50th state to join the Union -- is likely its beaches, like beautiful Waimea Beach on Oahu's North Shore. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen This beautiful U.S. state - far out in the Pacific Ocean - is also known for surfing, volcanoes, pineapple, hula dancing and perfect weather. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen The Hawaiian archipelago was formed by volcanic activity, and many of the state's volcanoes remain active. The Kilauea Volcano in Hawaii Volcanoes National Park on the Big Island glows under a starry sky. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Hawaii Volcanoes National Park is one of seven national parks in the state and one of the most popular. It's one of the few places in the world where you can witness volcanic action firsthand. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Hawaii's volcanic geology means that many of the island's beaches are covered in black sand. Punaluu Black Sand Beach on Hawaii's Kua coast is one of the most famous. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Retrace the flow of Hawaii Island's lava by taking a walk through the Thurston Lava Tube, a 500-year-old formation that once held a river of lava. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Hawaii's volcanic past (and present) is evident all over the Big Island. Some of the island's roads have even been rendered impassable by lava flows. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Haleakala National Park on the island of Maui is home to the island's highest peak of the same name, jutting 10,023 feet above sea level. Many visitors wake up early to catch a sunset from the summit of the volcanic peak. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen East of Waikiki Beach sits Diamond Head Crater, and perched on its cliffs is the Diamond Head Lighthouse, built in the late nineteenth century. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Kauai, the oldest of Hawaii's main islands, is a land of lush valleys, soaring cliffs and cascading waterfalls. Manawaiopuna Falls, one of the most spectacular, is typically reached by helicopter. Getty Images/Zoonar RF Fullscreen Hawaii isn't typically associated with snow, but when you head to the top of Mauna Kea -- the world's tallest mountain if measured from the ocean floor -- you might find some. It's home to the world's biggest telescope and is a favorite locale among star gazers. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen The island of Lanai remains one of Hawaii's most pristine inhabited islands -- home to some of the state's best beaches and natural scenery, like the Kaholo Cliffs. Pierce M Myers Photography/Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Hawaii's largest metropolitan area is on Oahu. The capital city, Honolulu blends Hawaii's natural beauty with all the modern luxuries of a city. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen At the heart of Honolulu sits Waikiki Beach, former playground to Hawaiian royalty and home of a beautiful beach and some of the state's best nightlife. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen One of Hawaii's most renowned cultural pastimes is that of hula dancing -- a uniquely Hawaiian dance you can learn (or just watch) on many of the islands. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Not all of Hawaii's activities involve the water. The Kalalau trail on Kauai often ranks among the world's most beautiful hiking trails, but it's also one of the most dangerous. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Those who brave the 11-mile Kalalau trail beginning at Kee Beach (pictured), with its crumbly trail bed and sheer drop-offs, are rewarded with the chance to experience one of the state's most remote stretches of sand, Kalalua Beach. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Hawaii is one of the nation's most multicultural states. The state's Asian heritage can be seen at The Great Buddha statue at Lahaina on Maui -- the largest Buddha statue of its kind outside of Japan. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Kohola is the Hawaiian word for humpback whale, and an estimated two thirds of the Northern Pacific humpback whale population come to the waters of Hawaii to breed and raise their young. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Even when it's not whale season, the waters off Hawaii's islands teem with life. Some of the state's best diving and snorkeling can be found in Molokini crater, a crescent-shaped marine sanctuary off the coast of Maui. Getty Images Fullscreen The clear, blue waters of Hawaii make the perfect playground for divers and snorkelers of all levels. Thinkstock Fullscreen In the biologically rich waters off the coast of Hawaii, it's possible to spot Hawaiian green sea turtles, manta rays and dolphins. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen The seven-mile-long stretch of sand known as Polihale sits within Polihale State Park on the island of Kauai. Journeying to the beach via a bumpy dirt road is worth it for the sunset views alone. Flickr/Justin Ornellas Fullscreen For leisurely hiking on the Big Island, head to Akaka Falls State Park, where it's possible to see two waterfalls on the short half-mile hike. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Hawaii Island, also called the Big Island, is the state's youngest, largest and still-growing island. On this island, you can laze on a beach and walk through the snow in a single day. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Hawaii is a veritable playground for water sports enthusiasts. Each year, the world's best windsurfers come to Hookipa Beach Park on Maui to compete. Getty Images Fullscreen It's hard to beat a Hawaiian sunset, and it's equally hard deciding which island (or part of an island) enjoys the best ones. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen The 17-mile stretch of emerald cliffs on Kauai's coast has become one of Hawaii's most famous sights. The Napali Coast can only be accessed on land by the Kalalau Trail. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Anyone who's seen the hit TV series "Lost" will recognize Mokuleia Beach Park in North Shore, Oahu. The beaches here are remote enough that you could easily spend a day without seeing another human being. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Hike to Rainbow Falls in Wailuku River State Park on the Big Island on a sunny day, and you'll quickly see how the falls got its name. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen For a road trip, island-style, hop in the car, turn on some tunes and drive the road to Hana -- a three hour drive from from Lahaina or Kihei with plenty to see and do along the way. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen One of the many stops on the scenic Road to Hana is the Keanae Congregational Church, built from lava rocks and coral mortar in 1860. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Hawaii has long been a favorite destination for honeymooners, and for a romantic sunset, try aptly named Sweetheart Rock on Lanai. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Waimea Canyon on Kauai, nicknamed "The Grand Canyon of the Pacific," stretches for 14 miles and is at points more than 3,600 feet deep. Getty Images Fullscreen Waipio Valley, or the Valley of Kings, sits on the northern coast of Hawaii Island and has one of the state's most breathtaking scenic overlooks. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Life on Oahu's North Shore, famed the world over for its excellent surfing, centers on the charming town of Haleiwa, the artistic and cultural hub of the area. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Surfing is believed to have originated in Polynesia and was once a sport of only Hawaiian royalty. Today, surfers from around the globe come to catch Hawaii's world-class waves. Kirk Lee Aeder, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Along Hawaii's Hamakua Coast, visitors will find lush jungles, waterfalls and stunning views of the Pacific Ocean. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Hawaii's cultural history dates back centuries, and you can learn about it at sites like Puukohola Heiau National Historic Site, a once sacred place of worship for native Hawaiians. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen The Kealakekua Bay State Historical Park was the site of first significant contact between native Hawaiians and Westerners. Here, visitors can see kii, sacred carvings of deities or ancestral spirits. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Saint Peter's By-the-Sea Catholic Church sits right on the water on the island of Hawaii's Kona coast. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Hawaii is a golfer's heaven, with more than 70 courses to choose from. Kirk Lee Aeder, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Kapaa, on the east side of Kauai, is a great destination for shopping, biking and water sports of all kinds. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Drive through Central Oahu, and you'll likely see vast expanses of pineapple fields. Visit the Dole Plantation to brave the 1.7-mile pineapple maze. Getty Images Fullscreen The Dole Plantation in Hawaii is one of the world's largest pineapple producers. Visitors can sample juicy fruits at markets throughout the islands. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Hawaii's biodiversity is astounding, and one of the more unusual species is the painted eucalyptus, which sheds its bark to reveal a rainbow of color underneath. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Kii pohaku -- Hawaiian petroglyphs -- can be found at more than 100 sites scattered throughout the islands. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Visiting Molokai is like stepping back in time. One of the island's most charming experiences occurs each Friday night when the island's elders gather for an evening of live music and hula at Hotel Molokai. Dana Edmunds, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Built in 1923 by James Dole, Hotel Lanai was the first hotel on Lanai Island and remains one of the most intimate, with only 11 guest rooms. LHP/Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Parts of Lanai Island, like Keahiakawelo, have an almost lunar landscape, in contrast to Hawaii's typically lush terrain. Which picture most makes you want to travel to Hawaii? Dana Edmunds, Hawaii Tourism Authority 101 CONNECT 33 TWEET 1 LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Hawaii marks the 56th anniversary of becoming the 50th state on Aug. 21. Take a virtual voyage around the state with these slideshows.
Hawaii's best beaches
 Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Sleepy Hanalei Beach has an end-of-the-road feel, and is home to stunning sunsets. Kauai Visitors Bureau Fullscreen Hikers will love the hike from Hanalei Valley up to the Hanalei Waterfall. Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Visitors to Hanalei should try the local Poi, a primary Polynesian staple food made from the underground plant stem or corm of the taro plant (known in Hawaiian as kalo). Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen About 10 miles east of Waikiki, Hanauma Bay offers the best snorkeling on Oahu. Heather Titus, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Couples will enjoy snorkeling in the tidepools of Hanauma Bay. Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen In addition to seaturtles, the clear turquoise waters of Hanauma Bay team with butterflyfish, triggerfish, pufferfish, moray eels, squid and many other bright quarry. Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Camera-ready Lanikai is a postcard-perfect beach. Erin M. Tagupa, KCOC Fullscreen The hill-like Mokulua Islands about a mile offshore from Lanikai will have you pulling out your camera in no time. Erin M. Tagupa, KCOC Fullscreen The water is generally calm, making Lanikai a safe spot for swimmers, children and anyone who wants tranquility at the beach. Erin M. Tagupa, KCOC Fullscreen Lanikai's isolation is made possible by the fact that there's no parking lot, and visitors must park on residential side streets, then walk to the beach via beach paths. Erin M. Tagupa, KCOC Fullscreen Lanaikai is Hawaiian for “heavenly water,” and although the beach is only about a mile long, its easy to see why its earned that name. Erin M. Tagupa, KCOC Fullscreen No beach is more famous in the Hawaiian Islands than Waikiki, a Honolulu neighbor fringed in white sand and birthplace of the cult of the Waikiki beach boy. Takahiro Masuda, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Hawaii's most recognized landmark is the unique profile of Diamond Head (Le'ahi), which sits prominently near the eastern edge of Waikiki's coastline. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Outrigger canoeing is a great way to ride the waves of Waikiki Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Waikiki beach is particularly beautiful at dusk, when most of the visitors have returned to their hotel for dinner. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Waikiki has the most active nightlife scene of all the Hawaiian beaches, providing plenty of entertainment by the ocean. Tor Johnson, Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen Waikiki might be more closely associated with surfing, from a tourist perspective, but the North Shore is its professional home. The swells here easily reach over 30 feet high. Hawaii Tourism Authority Fullscreen In summer, when the weather is generally calm, the scene flips, and the normally whipped-up Waimea Bay becomes a calm cove of blond sand hugged by a brace of lava rocks that draw colorful fish. Hawaii Tourism Authority Amazing animals
The new National Geographic program "Wild Hawaii" gives viewers a glance at the abundant wildlife on The Big Island. Here are some of the amazing creatures visitors to Hawaii may encounter. A hawksbill sea turtle hatchling emerges from its nest in Hawaii Volcanos National Park and heads for the ocean. Mike May, PangolIn Pictures Fullscreen A booby perches on a camera on East Island. Daniel Kwiatkowski, PangolIn Pictures Fullscreen A gaggle of nene - endemic Hawaiian geese - on the Big Island. In the 1950s, less than 30 nene were left. Today, there are about a thousand. Erica Zienowicz, PangolIn Pictures Fullscreen A monk seal rests on a remote beach on Molokai. Andrew Seestedt, PangolIn Pictures Fullscreen Monk seals sun themselves on Molokai. Andrew Seestedt, PangolIn Pictures Fullscreen Two green sea turtles bask on the black sands of Hawaii's Big Island. Erica Zienowicz, PangolIn Pictures Fullscreen A blackfooted albatross chick on Tern Island. Daniel Kwiatkowski, PangolIn Pictures Fullscreen Noddy terns tend to a chick on Tern Island. Daniel Kwiatkowski, PangolIn Pictures Fullscreen A sooty tern on Tern Island. Daniel Kwiatkowski, PangolIn Pictures Fullscreen A humpback whale plays in the water. Shutterstock Fullscreen Lemon and tiger sharks swim along the sea bed. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen A view from below as two giant oceanic manta rays soar overhead. Howard Chew Fullscreen A dolphin swims close the sea surface. Shutterstock Hawaii Volcanoes National Park
Nowhere in the U.S. can one simultaneously witness such merciless volatility and staggering beauty than at Hawai'i Volcanoes National Park. Associated Press Fullscreen Stretching from the 13,677-foot summit of Mauna Loa down to the ocean, the 333,000-acre park is situated in the southeastern portion of Hawai'i's largest island, aptly nicknamed the "Big Island." National Park Service/Mark Wasser Fullscreen The park is home to two of the world's most active volcanoes – Mauna Loa and Kīlauea. National Park Service Fullscreen Surface-flowing lava can be accessed via an arduous hike over uneven, sharp ground. Douglas Peebles Fullscreen Kilauea continuously erupts, so care has to be taken about how close you get. Kevin Eans, USA TODAY Fullscreen When the lava hits the ocean, the sight can be quite spectacular. Kevin Eans, USA TODAY Fullscreen As the sun sets, hikers watch lava from from Kilauea Volcano flow into the Pacific Ocean. Kevin Eans, USA TODAY Fullscreen After it cools, hiking is possible over the fields of lava. Kevin Eans, USA TODAY Fullscreen Hikers are silhouetted by the glow of lava flowing into the Pacific Ocean from from Kilauea Volcano. Kevin Eans, USA TODAY Fullscreen The park features lava fields, rain forests, deserts, and fragile ecosystems all at the mercy of an unpredictable force of nature. National Park Service Photo/ Michael Szoenyi Fullscreen Halema'uma'u Crater puts on a show with its night glow at Hawai'i Volcanoes National Park. National Park Service/Michael Szoenyi Fullscreen The lower slopes of Kīlauea demonstrate the many stages of forest regeneration. National Park Service Fullscreen The volcano's barren large caldera (measuring about three miles across) descends into thick forest of lichens and ferns. National Park Service Fullscreen A rain forest on the volcano's windward side transforms into the Ka'ī Desert along the southwestern slope. National Park Service/Jay Robinson Fullscreen In addition to a varied landscape of rain forests, deserts, rift zones, and craters, the park features cultural sites highlighting the culture of the Polynesian settlers who first arrived on these islands around 1,500 years ago. National Park Service/Jay Robinson Fullscreen Visitors fortunate enough to witness an eruption of Kīlauea (from a safe distance, or better yet, a helicopter) can watch fresh lava creep over black molten rock formed from former flows and slide into the ocean in a giant cloud of steam. National Park Service/Charlene Meyers Fullscreen Whether on a short visit or a multi-day vacation, you will find adventure and spectacular views set against a volcanic backdrop. National Park Service/Jay Robinson Fullscreen Over 150 miles of trails interconnect through the park and offer exploration for all ages and abilities, ranging from wheelchair accessible paved trails to hikes only the most seasoned hikers should tackle. National Park Service/Jessica Ferracane Fullscreen Park rangers give presentations to educate visitors about the volcanic landscape and lead guests on guided walks. National Park Service/Jay Robinson Fullscreen Thurston Lava Tube offers a cave-like system to hike through, showcasing the trail lava once flowed hundreds of years ago. National Park Service/Michael Szoenyi Pineapple cuisine
Located on Anaehoomalu Bay in the scenic Waikoloa Beach Resort, Lava Lava Beach Club’s open-air restaurant and bar is situated right on the beach. The pineapple fried rice bowl is attractively served in a half-pineapple, producing an island-style feel best appreciated during sunset. Toby Hoogs Photography Fullscreen Visitors to Maui’s premier luxury resort make a point of checking out the weekly Market Night at DUO, where a Hawaiian Reuben with pineapple kimchi, fried pickles and Maui onion dip is offered. Maui Gold pineapple is used to create a pineapple kimchi instead of the Reuben’s traditional sauerkraut. Four Seasons Resort Maui at Wailea Fullscreen As the flagship restaurant of Oahu’s most decorated luxury resort, La Mer is renowned for its upscale, gourmet fare. Featuring delicate cuts of fresh seafood, the Salade de Fruit de Mer springs to life thanks to a fennel and pineapple vinaigrette. Halekulani Fullscreen Hotel Wailea's guests relax by the pool with tropical, all-natural cocktails. The Piña de Pele (Cazadores Silver Tequila, fresh lime juice and Maui Gold pineapple juice) places a spicy spin on a traditional pineapple cocktail by using fresh jalapeño syrup. Before pouring, mixologists dip the rim of the glass in a small plate of honey and then into a mixture of red clay and pink Himalayan sea salt. Hotel Wailea Fullscreen Guests of the 'ULU Ocean Grill at Four Seasons Resort Hualalai enjoy “R.S.A.” (regional, seasonal and artisanal) cuisine in a beautiful setting under the stars. Joshua Fletcher Fullscreen On the dessert menu, the intricate pineapple poke features compressed vanilla-accented pineapple, meyer lemon pound cake, Puna chevre ice cream and white chocolate brittle. Joshua Fletcher Fullscreen At the The Royal Hawaiian’s Mai Tai Bar, the Smokin’ Mai Tai features a smoke infusion and caramelized pineapple chunks. Visitors to the oceanfront setting relax to the sounds of tropical music and live local entertainment at sunset. The Royal Hawaiian Fullscreen On the stunning northern coast of Kauai, guests of the St. Regis Resort Princeville enjoy a delicate dessert made with thinly-sliced pineapple that's filled with white chocolate and panna cotta made from local Koloa Rum. The Hala Kahiki dish gets a cooling kick from a portion of handcrafted raspberry sorbet that benefits from a touch of sherry vinegar. St. Regis Resort Princeville Fullscreen Guests looking to relax at the top-rated Four Seasons Resort Lanai at Manele Bay unwind with the inventive Smoky Thrill cocktail. Local kiawe (mesquite) wood is used to smoke fresh pineapple, which is then muddled with caramelized calamansi limes and Lehua Honey syrup. Old Lâhainâ Spiced Rum is added, and the concoction is shaken then poured into a Bordeaux glass. A floater of Sammy’s Red Head Beach Bar Rum is added, and the drink is completed with a pineapple garnish. Four Seasons Resort Lanai at Manele Bay Fullscreen The Fairmont Orchid’s award-winning, open-air restaurant serves innovative, locally-inspired cuisine. The macadamia nut-crusted wild boar chop entree is served with Molokai sweet potatoes, pineapple salsa in an ulu (breadfruit) cup, and a smoked pineapple ponzu sauce. The Fairmont Orchid Fullscreen For dessert, a Hawaiian chili pineapple sorbet gets a sour kick from li hing mui sugar. The Fairmont Orchid Fullscreen Named after the brief but awe-inspiring daily sunset on the Kohala Coast, the Malolo Lounge at Hilton Waikoloa Village’s 180-Seconds cocktail features four rums, zesty pineapple and other fruit juices. The bar’s signature cocktails are island-inspired twists on the classics, using fresh, local ingredients and house-made syrups and juices. John De Mello, courtesy of Hilton Waikoloa Fullscreen One of the state's most decorated culinary masterminds, chef Mavro produces rosemary Hawaiian pineapple and semifreddo at his namesake restaurant in Honolulu. He marinates fresh pineapple in rosemary, then cooks it slowly in the oven at 200 degrees. In addition to delicate portions of homemade coconut milk sorbet and Szechuan peppercorn semifreddo, the dessert features macadamia nut crumbs, candied rosemary sprig and sauce of guava kanten. Chef Mavro Fullscreen Boasting breathtaking views of the Big Island, Kamuela Provision Company serves this light, refreshing piña colada tapioca at Hilton Waikoloa Village. The tropical flavors of fresh local pineapple and coconut and smooth texture of tapioca pearls combine to yield a fun spin on a traditional comfort food. Hilton Waikoloa Village Fullscreen At his Waikiki outpost in trendy The MODERN Honolulu, Iron Chef Morimoto serves a dish he was inspired to create by applying a Japanese cooking technique (tempura) to local (pineapple) and Western (Iberico ham) ingredients. Topped with sea salt, micro mint, olive oil drizzle and shichimi togarashi, each bite is complemented by an inventive wasabi tatziki (yogurt, cucumber, yuzu, wasabi and Japanese sugar). Hopper Stone/stonefoto.com Fullscreen One of the most popular cocktails at one of Waikiki’s most popular resorts, the Pineapple Express sees house-infused pineapple vodka served straight-up in a chilled glass, garnished with a wedge of local pineapple. Hyatt Regency Waikiki Beach Resort & Spa Fullscreen This very Hawaiian spin on beignets sees three-inch pineapple spears dipped in Mana Wheat Beer batter, then lightly fried and seasoned with cinnamon and sugar. These warm pineapple treats are served with caramel rum sauce and vanilla ice cream at Jimmy Buffett’s at the Beachcomber in Honolulu. Nicole Sandry Fullscreen The award-winning Ko’s tropical signature cocktail includes locally-grown Maui Gold Pineapple muddled with Maui’s Sammy’s Beach Bar Rum, a squeeze of lime juice and a dash of simple syrup. Served in a sugar-rimmed martini glass with a squeeze of lime, it’s the perfect cocktail to sip poolside under the Maui sun. The Fairmont Kea Lani Fullscreen The Mauna Kea Beach Hotel’s Manta Pineapple spins local pineapple on its head. Mauna Kea Beach Hotel Fullscreen Chunks of pineapple are shown to the deep freezer, then a hole is drilled and filled with berry sauce and coconut mousse. The end result is one of the Big Island’s most innovative pineapple desserts. Mauna Kea Beach Hotel Fullscreen Mixologist Dave Newman manipulates local pineapple in a number of ways to produce award-winning cocktails at Honolulu's Pint + Jigger. Pint + Jigger Fullscreen In 'Reviving the Pine', Newman combines fresh pineapple, toasted Jack Daniel's barrel chips and Tanqueray 10 in a mason jar, then heats it sous vide for 24 hours at 115 degrees. After straining out and chilling the barrel chips, three ounces of the mixture are poured into an Absinthe-rinsed coupe and garnished with a lemon peel. The wood flavors are balanced by the sweetness of the pineapple. Pint + Jigger Fullscreen For an upscale take on the state's most beloved cooling treat -- shave ice – Honolulu’s MW Restaurant vacuum-seals pineapple with lemongrass and kaffir lime to intensify the flavor. The pineapple is juiced and macerated with lime, then frozen and shaved. For the pineapple-coconut "snow," the kitchen blends pineapple juice with coconut milk, then aerates and freezes the concoction. Throw in mochi ice cream and coconut tapioca, and the delicious dessert is complete. MW Restaurant Fullscreen Once decorated as the "World's Best Mai Tai," Trump Waikiki Hotel’s award-winning take on the classic drink uses caramelized pineapple, a homemade sorbet made from pineapple and Bacardi Gold, and a fresh pineapple wedge for garnish. Other components of the Ilikea Mai Tai include Bacardi 8, Amaretto, Canton Ginger liqueur and kaffir lime sour. Trump Waikiki Hotel 101 CONNECT 33 TWEET 1 LINKEDIN 1 //usat.ly/1Jlcvcz TOP VIDEOS
